Description: Amino acids such as serine, cysteine and methionine play important roles in protein synthesis, anabolic metabolism, enzyme activity, and intracellular redox homeostasis. For example, cysteine is critical to redox metabolism by generating the universal antioxidant glutathione, while methionine catabolism produces the universal methyl donor S-adenosylmethionine needed for the methylation of RNA, DNA, and proteins. NRF2, a transcription factor frequently deregulated in lung cancer, controls the expression of key serine/glycine biosynthesis to support glutathione and nucleotide production. Moreover, appropriate generation of intracellular pyrimidine pools also sustain DNA synthesis and repair. This session will evaluate all three aspects in a series of presentations designed to reveal how these pathways might be exploited to develop new cancer therapies, especially for difficult to treat tumors.
